title-group.article-title: Association of a healthy lifestyle with mortality risk among individuals with osteoarthritis: a prospective cohort study of the UK Biobank

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Orthopaedics, Xiangya Hospital, Central South University, Changsha, People's Republic of China
3Hunan Key Laboratory of Joint Degeneration and Injury, Xiangya Hospital, Central South University, Changsha, People's Republic of China

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Osteoarthritis is common and often coexists with other chronic conditions, which may contribute to increased all-cause mortality. Maintaining a healthy lifestyle contributes to increased longevity; however, considering physical functions and physiological conditions of patients with osteoarthritis differ from the general population, the impact of maintaining a healthy lifestyle in these patients remains uncertain, which poses a challenge to implementing-related interventions in this population. This study aims to examine the association between healthy lifestyle factors and mortality in individuals with osteoarthritis.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This cohort study enrolled 52 973 participants from the UK Biobank who met the criteria for osteoarthritis as defined via hospitalisation or primary care records. Seven lifestyle factors, consisting of smoking, alcohol intake, physical activity, diet, television watching time, sleep duration and social connection, were included. HRs (with 95% CIs) for total and cause-specific mortality were estimated by Cox proportional hazards regression models.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 4637 deaths were recorded during the follow-up period. Seven healthy lifestyle factors were all independently associated with a low mortality risk. When compared with participants meeting only 0–2 healthy lifestyle criteria, the adjusted HRs (95% CI) for those adhering to 3–7 factors were 0.70 (0.62 to 0.78), 0.60 (0.54 to 0.67), 0.49 (0.44 to 0.54), 0.46 (0.41 to 0.52) and 0.42 (0.36 to 0.49), respectively (p for trend <0.001). A dose-response pattern was also observed for mortality from cancer, cardiovascular, respiratory and digestive diseases (all p for trend <0.001), whereas no significant trend emerged for mortality due to neurodegenerative diseases.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Adherence to a greater number of healthy lifestyle factors was associated with a significantly lower risk of mortality among individuals with osteoarthritis. Our findings hold important public health implications and provide empirical evidence that adhering to a healthy lifestyle could mitigate the burdens caused by osteoarthritis.

institution-wrap.institution: Key Projects of Postgraduate Independent Exploration and Innovation of Central South University
Postgraduate Scientific Research Innovation Project of Hunan Province

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: This study used data from over 52 000 individuals with osteoarthritis from the UK Biobank, enabling robust statistical analyses and detailed adjustment for potential confounders.
It is the first to evaluate the association between a composite healthy lifestyle score and all-cause and cause-specific mortality in individuals with osteoarthritis.

Seven lifestyle factors—including emerging ones such as sleep duration, social connection and television viewing time—were simultaneously evaluated for their independent and combined effects on mortality.
Despite extensive adjustments, the observational design limits causal inference and residual confounding by unmeasured or poorly measured factors cannot be ruled out.
The majority of participants were white and from the UK, which may limit the applicability of the findings to more diverse populations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Osteoarthritis is the most common degenerative joint disease, affecting more than 500 million adults worldwide.1 Osteoarthritis leads to pain, disability and decreased quality of life.2 It was reported that individuals with osteoarthritis have ~20% excess mortality as compared with age-matched controls, which appears attributable to comorbid conditions such as obesity, cardiovascular disease and diabetes.3 Therefore, it is important to identify risk factors for mortality among individuals with osteoarthritis, especially the modifiable ones, and to implement effective measures for preventing adverse outcomes.

Various lifestyle factors, such as diet, smoking, alcohol consumption, physical activity, television watching, sleep duration and social connection, have been proposed to be associated with longevity.48 These lifestyle factors are modifiable and related interventions have been recommended to the general population by the WHO since 2017. However, some healthy lifestyle factors that benefit the general population may have different effects on individuals with osteoarthritis. For example, smoking has been found to decrease the overall risk of being a candidate for total knee arthroplasty, possibly due to the proliferation of joint cartilage cells in response to nicotine stimulation.9 Additionally, the relationship between moderate alcohol consumption and osteoarthritis has not been fully established, with some studies showing a positive association and others reporting a negative one.1013 In vitro experiments showed that alcohol can inhibit the growth of chondrocytes, while polyphenols commonly found in alcoholic beverages can prevent cartilage degradation and joint damage.1416 Currently, limited evidence exists on how these lifestyle factors relate to mortality specifically in individuals with osteoarthritis, who often present with complex health profiles. Clarifying this relationship could enhance the implementation of effective healthy lifestyle interventions in this population.17 18

Using data collected from The UK Biobank study, we examined the relation of seven healthy lifestyle factors, that is, no current smoking, moderate alcohol consumption, healthy diet pattern, regular physical activity, adequate sleep duration, short television watching time and appropriate social connection to all-cause mortality in individuals with osteoarthritis. Identifying and quantitatively assessing the potentially modifiable lifestyle factors holds important public health implications for this population.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The UK Biobank is a large, population-based cohort that enrolled over 500 000 individuals aged 40–69 years between 2006 and 2010. At 22 assessment centres across England, Scotland and Wales, participants completed detailed questionnaires on health status and lifestyle behaviours, underwent physical examinations and provided biological samples.19 We included participants with a recorded diagnosis of osteoarthritis prior to their recruitment date. Individuals with a body mass index (BMI) below 18.5 kg/m² were excluded to minimise bias related to potential underlying frailty or comorbidities. The primary analysis was restricted to participants with complete information on all covariates of interest. The diagnosis of osteoarthritis was identified by a three-character International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems 10th revision code (ICD-10) M17.20 These diagnoses were based on data linked from the primary care records, hospital admission records or self-reported medical condition.21

sec.title: Assessment of lifestyle factors
sec.p: We assessed seven modifiable lifestyle behaviours in this study. Four of the lifestyle factors were well-established factors (ie, smoking status, alcohol intake, physical activity, diet),5 whereas the other three were emerging factors (television watching time, sleep duration and social connection).6 22 23 All lifestyle data were obtained through self-administered touchscreen questionnaires at baseline. Detailed definitions of each lifestyle factor are provided in the online supplemental eMethods section of the Web Appendix.

Each lifestyle variable was assigned a value of 0 or 1, with 1 indicating adherence to a predefined healthy criterion: no current smoking (never or previous smoker), moderate alcohol consumption (women ≤1 drink per day, and men ≤2 drinks per day regularly), healthy diet pattern (adequate intake of at least 1.5 of 10 recommended food groups, with details provided in the online supplemental eMethods section of the Web Appendix), regular physical activity (≥150 min/week of moderate activity, or ≥75 min/week of vigorous activity), adequate sleep duration (7–8 hours/day),24 short television watching time (<4 hours/day),25 and appropriate social connection (ie, moderately active and active social connection status).26 A composite healthy lifestyle score was calculated by summing the values for all seven factors, with higher scores representing greater adherence to an overall healthy lifestyle. Because the percentage of participants with low healthy lifestyle scores is low, we collapsed scores of 0, 1 and 2 into one category.

sec.title: Ascertainment of outcomes
sec.p: The outcome variables included all-cause mortality and cause-specific mortality, that is, death from cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, neurodegenerative disease, digestive disease and other causes. Information about the date and underlying cause of death was obtained from the National Health Service Information Centre (for England and Wales) and the National Health Service Central Register Scotland (for Scotland). Causes of death were classified using ICD-10 code. Details of the data linkage procedure are available online at http://content.digital.nhs.uk/services.

sec.title: Assessment of covariates
sec.p: The following variables were considered as covariates: age (years); sex (male or female); ethnicity (white, black, Asian, mixed or other); education (higher—college/university degree or other professional qualification; upper secondary—second/final stage of secondary education; lower secondary—first stage of secondary education; vocational—work-related practical qualifications; or other); social deprivation (Townsend Deprivation Index); and employment (currently employed or not); BMI; prevalent diseases (yes or no); osteoarthritis duration (continuous, years); pain medication use at baseline (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, opioids and anilides). Prevalent diseases were defined as the presence of any major baseline comorbidity, including cardiovascular disease, hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, diabetes, cancer, depression, neurodegenerative disorders, lung diseases and digestive system diseases. These were identified using a combination of self-reported diagnoses and hospital admission records with validated ICD codes available in the UK Biobank.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Baseline characteristics are summarised as the mean (SD) for normally distributed continuous variables, median (IQR) for skewed continuous variables and frequency (percentage) for categorical variables.

Follow-up time for each participant was calculated in person-years from the recruitment date (2006–2010) until the date of death or the end of follow-up (December 2020 for England and Wales and November 2020 for Scotland and elsewhere), whichever came first. Associations between individual lifestyle factors and all-cause mortality were assessed using Cox proportional hazards models, adjusting age, sex, education, Townsend Deprivation Index, employment, BMI, prevalent diseases, osteoarthritis duration and pain medication use to control potential confounders. When the relation of each lifestyle factor to all-cause mortality was examined, mutual adjustment for the other lifestyle factors was also applied. Sex-stratified analyses were conducted to evaluate the relationship between healthy lifestyle score and all-cause mortality in men and women. We used the same approach to examine healthy lifestyle scores in relation to all-cause mortality overall, as well as within age subgroups. Cause-specific mortality, including deaths from cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, neurodegenerative disease, digestive disease and other causes (ie, all other causes not classified into the above categories), was also analysed in relation to lifestyle score. In a supplementary analysis, we exactly matched each osteoarthritis participant to up to two non-osteoarthritis participants on age, sex, BMI (±1 kg/m²) and recruitment year, and compared all-cause mortality between the matched cohorts using Cox proportional hazards models before and after covariate adjustment. The proportional hazards assumption was evaluated using Schoenfeld residuals. Population-attributable risk (PAR) values were estimated to determine the proportion of deaths potentially preventable if all individuals achieved a lifestyle score of at least 3, 4, 5, 6 or 7. We performed multiple imputation with chained equations (five datasets) to deal with the missing exposure and covariate data. Additionally, we excluded participants with poor self-rated health and those who died within 2 or 4 years of follow-up to minimise potential reverse causation.
All statistical tests were two-sided, and a p value<0.05 was considered significant. All analyses were performed using Stata SE, V.15 (StataCorp).

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Patients and the public were not involved in the development of the research question or outcome measures, in the design of the study, or in the recruitment and conduct of the study. As this study was a secondary analysis of existing data from the UK Biobank cohort, there was no direct involvement of patients in these processes. The results of this study will not be disseminated directly to participants but will be made publicly available through open-access publication.

sec.title: Population characteristics
sec.p: Baseline characteristics of 52 973 individuals with osteoarthritis are presented in table 1. The median age was 60.6 years, and 40.3% were men. The proportion of healthy lifestyle scores of 0–2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 was 5.3%, 11.5%, 22.3%, 29.3%, 23.7% and 7.9%, respectively.

caption.title: Baseline characteristics of participants with osteoarthritis by lifestyle score category

tr.td: Never or short television watching time, n (%)
Other or prefer not to answer

fn.p: Data are median (IQR) for continuous variables or n (%) for categorical variables.
BMI, body mass index; NSAIDs, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; SD, standard deviation; SMD, standardised mean difference.

sec.title: Association between individual lifestyle factors and risk of all-cause mortality
sec.p: During a total of 610 414 person-years of follow-up, 4637 deaths occurred. As shown in table 2, compared with no current smoking participants, the adjusted HR and its 95% CI of mortality was 2.15 (1.99 to 2.33) for those current smokers (Model 1). Never or excessive alcohol consumption levels had a higher mortality risk compared with moderate alcohol consumption (HR 1.15 (95% CI: 1.08 to 1.22)). Following an unhealthy diet pattern and engaging in irregular physical activity were associated with a higher mortality rate, the corresponding HRs were 1.07 (95% CI: 1.01 to 1.14) and 1.23 (95% CI: 1.15 to 1.30). Short or long duration of sleep versus adequate sleeping duration was associated with increased risk of mortality (HR: 1.14 (95% CI: 1.07 to 1.21)). Participants with longer television-watching time had higher mortality compared with those short television-watching participants (HR: 1.11 (95% CI: 1.05 to 1.18)). Furthermore, isolated social connection can also significantly increase the risk of all-cause mortality (HR 1.27 (95% CI: 1.16 to 1.38)) (table 2). After adjusting for additional covariates, similar results were still observed (Model 2 and Model 3). When stratified by gender, the relationship between television viewing time and mortality weakened in men, while the relationship between diet and mortality weakened in women (online supplemental eTables 1 and 2 in the Web Appendix). In a supplementary matched analysis (1:2 matching on age, sex, BMI and recruitment year), the osteoarthritis group (n=52 842) and matched controls (n=103 306) had similar baseline characteristics. In unadjusted models, osteoarthritis was associated with a slightly higher mortality risk (HR 1.06, 95% CI: 1.02 to 1.09), but this association was attenuated and became non-significant after adjustment for covariates (HR 0.99, 95% CI: 0.96 to 1.03), suggesting osteoarthritis itself may not independently increase mortality risk.

caption.title: HR (95% CI) of all-cause mortality according to individual modifiable healthy lifestyle factors

fn.p: Low-risk lifestyle factors: no current smoking, moderate alcohol consumption (no more than one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men on a relatively regular frequency), healthy diet (adequate intake of at least 1.5 of 10 recommended food groups), regular physical activity (MET moderate or high), adequate sleep duration (7–8 hours/day), less television watching time (<4 hours/day) and appropriate social connection (not isolated).

Model 1, adjustment for age (years), sex (women or men), BMI, ethnicity (white, black, Asian, mixed or other), education (higher (college/university degree or other professional qualification), upper secondary (second/final stage of secondary education), lower secondary (first stage of secondary education), vocational (work-related practical qualifications) or other), Townsend Deprivation Index and employment (currently employed or not); Model 2, further adjustment for prevalent diseases (yes or no) and osteoarthritis duration (continuous, years) based on Model 1; Model 3, further adjustment for pain medication use at baseline (NSAIDs, opioids and anilides) based on Model 1 and Model 2. Lifestyle factors were mutually adjusted for analyses on the association of each individual lifestyle factor with all-cause mortality risk.
BMI, body mass index; MET, Metabolic Equivalent of Task; NSAIDs, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

sec.title: Association between lifestyle score and risk of all-cause mortality
sec.p: An inverse association was observed between the healthy lifestyle score and all-cause mortality. As shown in table 3, compared with those with a healthy lifestyle score of 0–2, the adjusted HRs of mortality for participants with scores of 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 were 0.65 (95% CI: 0.58 to 0.73), 0.53 (95% CI: 0.48 to 0.59), 0.42 (95% CI: 0.38 to 0.47), 0.39 (95% CI: 0.35 to 0.44) and 0.35 (95% CI: 0.30 to 0.41), respectively (p for trend <0.001) (Model 1). When adjusted for additional covariates, the HRs of mortality for participants with scores of 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 were 0.69 (95% CI: 0.61 to 0.77), 0.58 (95% CI: 0.52 to 0.65), 0.47 (95% CI: 0.42 to 0.52), 0.44 (95% CI: 0.39 to 0.49) and 0.40 (95% CI: 0.34 to 0.47) in the Model 2 (p for trend <0.001), and the HRs of mortality for participants with scores of 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 were 0.70 (95% CI: 0.62 to 0.78), 0.60 (95% CI: 0.54 to 0.67), 0.49 (95% CI: 0.44 to 0.54), 0.46 (95% CI: 0.41 to 0.52) and 0.42 (95% CI: 0.36 to 0.49) in the Model 3 (p for trend <0.001) (table 3). Consistent inverse associations were also observed across different baseline age groups (40–50, 51–60 and 61–70 years), although the effect estimates in the youngest group were less precise due to fewer events (online supplemental eTable 3 in the Web Appendix). The PAR for all-cause mortality increased with increasing healthy lifestyle scores, from 1.7% for a score of ≥2% to 6.0%, 11.9%, 19.7%, 23.7% and 29.1% for scores of ≥3, ≥4, ≥5, ≥6 and ≥7, respectively (table 4).

caption.title: HR (95% CI) of cause specific mortality according to combined modifiable healthy lifestyle factors

tr.th: Number of modifiable healthy lifestyle factors*

fn.p: Model 1, adjustment for age (years), sex (women or men), BMI, ethnicity (white, black, Asian, mixed or other), education (higher (college/university degree or other professional qualification), upper secondary (second/final stage of secondary education), lower secondary (first stage of secondary education), vocational (work-related practical qualifications) or other), Townsend Deprivation Index and employment (currently employed or not); Model 2, further adjustment for prevalent diseases (yes or no) and osteoarthritis duration (continuous, years) based on Model 1; Model 3, further adjustment for pain medication use at baseline (NSAIDs, opioids and anilides) based on Model 1 and Model 2. Lifestyle factors were mutually adjusted for analyses on the association of each individual lifestyle factor with all-cause mortality risk.
Mortality from causes other than cancer, CVD, respiratory disease, neurodegenerative disease or digestive disease.
BMI, body mass index; CVD, Cardiovascular Disease; NSAIDs, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

caption.title: Relative and population attributable risks of all-cause mortality for groups defined by combinations of modifiable healthy lifestyle factors

tr.td: Number of modifiable healthy lifestyle factors†

fn.p: The reference group in each comparison consists of individuals with fewer than the specified number of healthy lifestyle factors. HRs were adjusted for age (years), sex (women or men), BMI, ethnicity (white, black, Asian, mixed or other), education (higher (college/university degree or other professional qualification), upper secondary (second/final stage of secondary education), lower secondary (first stage of secondary education), vocational (work-related practical qualifications) or other), Townsend Deprivation Index, employment (currently employed or not).

Low-risk lifestyle factors: no current smoking, moderate alcohol consumption (no more than one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men on a relatively regular frequency), healthy diet (adequate intake of at least 1.5 of 10 recommended food groups), regular physical activity (MET moderate or high), adequate sleep duration (7–8 hours/day), less television watching time (<4 hours/day) and appropriate social connection (not isolated).
BMI, body mass index; MET, Metabolic Equivalent of Task; PAR%, population attributable risk per cent.

sec.title: Association between lifestyle score and risk of cause-specific mortality
sec.p: There was a significant inverse dose-response association between the healthy lifestyle score and mortality from cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, digestive disease and other causes (p for trend <0.001); however, no such pattern was observed for neurodegenerative disease (table 3). For example, HRs of mortality from cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease and digestive disease were 0.41 (95% CI: 0.33 to 0.52), 0.38 (95% CI: 0.28 to 0.54), 0.16 (95% CI: 0.09 to 0.30), 0.09 (95% CI: 0.03 to 0.29) for participants with the healthy lifestyle score 7 compared with those with scores of 0–2 (Model 1). After adjusting for additional covariates, similar results were still observed (Model 2 and Model 3).

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: Results did not change materially after performing multiple imputations for missing values of lifestyle factors and covariates (online supplemental eTable 4 in the Web Appendix). Similar findings were observed on excluding patients with poor self-rated health (online supplemental eTable 5 in the Web Appendix), as well as those who died within 2 or 4 years from baseline (online supplemental eTables 6 and 7 in the Web Appendix).

sec.title: Statement of principal findings
sec.p: In this cohort study of individuals with osteoarthritis, we found that adherence to healthy lifestyle factors, that is, balanced diet, abstaining from smoking, moderate alcohol consumption, regular physical activity, short television watching, adequate sleep duration and appropriate social connection, was significantly associated with reduced all-cause mortality, notably deaths from cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease and digestive disease. These findings highlight the critical role of adopting a healthy lifestyle in reducing mortality among individuals with osteoarthritis.

sec.title: Comparison with previous studies
sec.p: Traditional lifestyle factors have been extensively studied in relation to mortality risk in the general population. However, the impact of these lifestyle factors on osteoarthritis has yielded inconsistent results, which suggest the unique characteristics of osteoarthritis. Moreover, the influence of lifestyle factors on mortality rates specifically within the osteoarthritis population has not been widely investigated.

Smoking is considered a risk factor affecting the health of the general population; however, it has been found to decrease the overall risk of being a candidate for total knee arthroplasty.9 The impact of smoking on the mortality of individuals with osteoarthritis has long remained unclear. Our study revealed that abstaining from smoking may lower the risk of mortality for individuals with osteoarthritis. Meta-analyses of cohort studies on alcohol consumption and all-cause mortality suggest a J-shaped relationship, with the lowest mortality observed in those with low to moderate alcohol intake.27 Nevertheless, some studies have found that certain alcoholic beverages may have a protective effect against osteoarthritis. Our results from individuals with osteoarthritis are consistent with the findings in the general population. The relationship between physical activity and all-cause mortality in osteoarthritis patients has been explored in a study involving 3197 participants.28 This study found that sufficient physical activity can reduce all-cause mortality, which is consistent with our findings. Maintaining a healthy diet confers protective effects against elevated mortality risk,29 as evidenced by recent large-scale prospective studies in the general population,30 but there is no direct evidence in individuals with osteoarthritis. Our study confirms that a healthy dietary pattern is associated with a lower risk of mortality in these patients. Social connections have emerged as crucial for health and well-being.31 Our study shows that social connection significantly reduces mortality risk among individuals with osteoarthritis. A recent meta-analysis observed a U-shaped relationship between sleep duration and mortality risk, with both short and long sleep durations linked to increased all-cause mortality.32 In the current study, short or long sleep duration was significantly associated with an increased mortality risk. Sedentary behaviour, often reflected in prolonged television watching, has been linked to an increased risk of all-cause mortality, aligning with our findings in the osteoarthritis population.33

To our knowledge, no previous study has investigated the association between a healthy lifestyle score and mortality risk in individuals with osteoarthritis. Our findings indicate that a higher healthy lifestyle score correlates with reduced mortality risk from cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease and digestive disease, although not for neurodegenerative disease. Previous research has shown that a healthy lifestyle can lower the risk of developing neurodegenerative diseases, but these conditions typically are not immediately life-threatening, which may explain the attenuated specific mortality risk.34

sec.title: Potential mechanisms
sec.p: The biological mechanisms underlying the associations between lifestyle factors and health outcomes have been extensively investigated. Overall, increasing evidence suggests that chronic low-grade systemic inflammation plays a central role in mediating these associations.35 This mild but persistent inflammatory state can be triggered by factors such as physical inactivity, obesity, poor diet, disturbed sleep and circadian rhythms, social isolation and tobacco smoke. This inflammation contributes to ageing and many chronic diseases, ultimately influencing mortality risk.

Tobacco smoke contains a variety of harmful compounds that disrupt mitochondrial function, elevate oxidative stress and cause epigenetic changes.36 Thus, avoiding cigarette exposure is therefore a key strategy to lower the risk of disease and premature death. Moderate, regular alcohol consumption has been associated with reduced mortality compared with both infrequent and heavy drinking. This phenomenon may be partly explained by the observation that regular moderate drinkers often have better financial situations and higher social status, and potentially benefit from mild anti-inflammatory effects associated with moderate alcohol intake. However, it may also be influenced by the inclusion of individuals with pre-existing illnesses in the non-drinking group, as people often abstain from alcohol due to underlying health conditions. Biologically, moderate alcohol intake may reduce stress-related brain activity and cardiovascular risk,37 38 whereas excessive consumption promotes systemic inflammation, metabolic and mitochondrial dysfunction, gut barrier disruption and epigenetic changes, collectively increasing multiorgan damage and mortality.3941 Physical activity influences systemic immune and metabolic responses by stimulating pathways such as adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase phosphorylation, promoting organ health and enhancing survival probability.4244 A balanced diet not only supplies essential nutrients such as proteins, amino acids, vitamins and minerals, but also plays a crucial role in regulating systemic metabolic and inflammatory processes. For example, high dietary fibre intake can enhance the production of short-chain fatty acids by gut microbiota, which support gut barrier integrity and help modulate immune and inflammatory responses.45 46 Meanwhile, limiting saturated fat and increasing intake of unsaturated fats can improve lipid metabolism by reducing visceral and hepatic fat accumulation and lowering low density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.47 48 A healthy diet also facilitates better blood sugar control by improving insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.49 Overall, these pathways reduce the risk of major chronic diseases, including cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, ultimately lowering the risk of all-cause mortality. Sedentary behaviour is linked to higher circulating levels of inflammatory markers, such as interleukin-6 and C-reactive protein,5052 which are considered indicators of cellular senescence and may contribute to adverse health outcomes in older adults.53 Increasing evidence suggests that social connections impact specific biological pathways, such as blood pressure,54 oxidative stress,55 neuroendocrine dysregulation,56 chronic inflammation57 and gut-microbiome interactions.58 Social connections may influence biological health indirectly by shaping stress perception and related behaviours, including sleep, smoking and substance use.59 60

sec.title: Clinical and research implications
sec.p: Due to the unique nature of osteoarthritis, the impact of certain healthy lifestyle factors on patients with this condition remains uncertain, making the promotion of healthy lifestyles in this population a challenging task. Our study provides direct evidence that adherence to healthy lifestyle factors is associated with reduced mortality risk in individuals with osteoarthritis. These insights may encourage patients to adopt healthier habits and support healthcare providers in tailoring preventive strategies for this vulnerable population. In our study, only 7.9% of participants adhered to a healthy lifestyle (seven healthy factors). Meanwhile, 39.1% adopted four or fewer healthy lifestyle factors, indicating a substantial gap between current and ideal lifestyle practices. If individuals took responsibility for their own health, the global costs and burden of disease could be significantly reduced. Additionally, our study suggests that some lifestyle factors have a stronger impact on mortality than others, highlighting the potential value of targeting the most influential behaviours in public health policies.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: This study has several strengths. First, it leveraged a large sample with detailed data on potential confounders, enabling comprehensive analyses of cause-specific mortality and stratification by risk factors.5 Second, our study was the first to assess the combined impact of an overall healthy lifestyle on the osteoarthritis population. Considering the strong interrelations among lifestyle behaviours, applying a composite healthy lifestyle score allowed a holistic assessment of their joint impact on mortality in this population.

Several limitations should be noted. First, the cohort was predominantly Caucasian and UK-based, which may limit generalisability to other populations. Second, participants who died during the study period may have had pre-existing severe conditions at baseline. Although the study excluded deaths within the first 2–4 years of follow-up to mitigate this, the possibility of residual confounding remains. Third, due to the observational nature of the study, residual confounding is unavoidable. We cannot establish a causal relationship between lifestyle modifications and mortality in individuals with osteoarthritis, highlighting the need for well-designed interventional studies to confirm these findings. Finally, while we relied on hospital inpatient records, primary care data and self-reports to identify osteoarthritis cases, these sources may vary in diagnostic specificity. In particular, primary care records and self-reports might misclassify individuals with non-osteoarthritis musculoskeletal conditions as having osteoarthritis.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Adopting a healthy lifestyle was linked to a reduced mortality risk in individuals with osteoarthritis. Our findings have substantial public health implications, providing empirical evidence that maintaining a healthy lifestyle can reduce the burdens associated with osteoarthritis.

fn.p: Funding: NW is supported by the Postgraduate Scientific Research Innovation Project of Hunan Province (CX20230278) and the Key Projects of Postgraduate Independent Exploration and Innovation of Central South University (2023ZZTS0202).

Prepub: Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2024-092558).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Consent obtained directly from patient(s).

Ethics approval: The study was approved by the National Information Governance Board for Health and Social Care and the National Health Service North West Multicenter Research Ethics Committee (16/NW/0274; ethics approval for UK Biobank studies). All participants provided written informed consent before the data collection. The present study was conducted using data from the UK Biobank under approved application number 77646.
Data availability free text: We have included all available outputs in the main text or the Supplementary Material. Further enquiries could be sent to the corresponding author.

Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research. Refer to the Methods section for further details.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: Data are available upon reasonable request.
